awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards Millimeter Wave Communications for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
With the proliferation of bandwidth hungry mobile devices, dense deployments of users, and the proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, broadband spectrum needs have been continuously increasing in recent years. The use of the millimeter wave (mmWave) frequency bands is seen as a major way to address this spectrum crunch problem since large amounts of licensed and unlicensed bandwidths are available at these frequencies, leading to new standards being developed for 5G cellular and Wi-Fi using mmWave. In parallel, there have been unprecedented recent advances in commercial unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) technologies, which has resulted in their adoption in a wide range of applications, such as disaster relief, agricultural monitoring, wireless connectivity in rural areas, and hotspot connectivity for major sporting events. The proposed research in this project aims to study the foundations of mmWave communications in UAVs in a systematic manner using notions from wireless networks, communication theory, optimization theory, and software defined radios (SDRs), starting from channel sounding and characterization. The data collected from this project will be made public and disseminated via the 5G Millimeter Wave Channel Modeling Alliance. The project will train both graduate students and undergraduate students across multiple institutions in an emerging area of national interest.

A key challenge in any mmWave communication is that beamforming needs to be used in order to overcome the path loss. The use of mmWave on UAVs poses additional challenges and benefits. The challenges are primarily due to limited battery life and weight carrying capability of UAVs and the benefits accrue from the use of: 1) large bandwidth; 2) ability to implement 3D beamforming enabling improved spatial reuse; and 3) harnessing the UAV mobility to perform dynamic UAV clustering and interference management. The goal of this project is to address these fundamental challenges via a unique research collaboration focused on developing the next-generation of analytical and experimental tools for designing, modeling, optimizing, and testing mmWave UAV networks. Specific areas of study will include: (i) novel precoder designs for mmWave UAVs taking into account realistic propagation characteristics derived from channel sounding experiments; (ii) equalizer design for mmWave UAVs that trade-off beamwidth against equalizer structure; (iii) multiple access design for mmWave UAVs: code division and time division multiple access techniques will be revisited for mmWave UAV communications, for serving users that are accessed by the same transmitter beam; and (iv) optimal UAV placement for multi-hop wireless backhaul by investigating the use of UAVs as flying relays.

por.por_cntn:
With the proliferation of bandwidth hungry mobile devices and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, broadband spectrum needs have been continuously increasing in recent years. Use of millimeter wave (mmWave) frequency bands is seen as a major way to address this spectrum crunch problem. In parallel, there have been unprecedented recent advances in commercial unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) or drones technologies, which resulted in their adoption in a wide range of applications. Over the last five years, this project has successfully addressed multiple fundamental challenges that focused on developing the next-generation of analytical and experimental tools for designing, modeling, optimizing, and testing mmWave UAV networks. In particular, it has laid down the foundations of UAV-assisted mmWave communications across the physical (PHY), Medium Access Control (MAC), and network (NET) layers, by delivering the following outcomes.

At the PHY layer, this project has developed realistic channel models for UAV-assisted mmWave communications using ray tracing simulations. Such simulations clarified the angular and temporal characteristics of air-to-ground mmWave channels. Characterizing such UAV-assisted mmWave channels has contributed to achieving higher data rate through two approaches as follows. First, it was used towards developing a novel spatial covariance estimation problem for mmWave communications, which is critical for improving beamforming performance. Second, it was utilized towards developing non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) techniques, which are specifically designed for UAVs given the unique 3-dimensional geometry of drone communication topologies and hot spot service areas.

At the MAC layer, this project has delivered multiple interference management schemes for UAV-assisted Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) networks. First, ray-tracing simulation models were conducted for UAV-assisted IAB networks. Then, multiple UAV-associated parameters were optimally defined such as the 3-d positioning, transmission powers, and served users.

At the NET layer, this project has presented the benefits of having UAVs on the design of upper network layers such as designing long-range multi-hop multi-path routing schemes, given the underlying short-range mmWave communication. More specifically, this project has maximized mmWave-based mesh network algebraic connectivity via optimally deploying a number of UAVs and it has also enabled multiple parallel paths for reliable data transmissions.

Security of UAV-assisted mmWave communication has been also investigated in this project. For example, physical layer security enhancements for mmWave drones, when beams of different widths and NOMA are utilized for serving ground users, were introduced. Moreover, a hybrid analog-digital mmWave precoders for physical-layer security in mmwave communication, which is aimed to reduce hardware complexity and power consumption, was also developed. At the upper network layers, efficient authentication schemes of drones to mmWave wireless mesh networks in post-disaster scenarios were designed. 

This project has gone beyond theoretical evaluation of proposed schemes by developing a channel sounding testbed using software-defined radio (SDR) kits. Such testbed operates over 60 GHz and has narrow bandwidth of 10 MHz. Finally, performance characterization of real deployment of mmWave cellular networks was conducted using commercial 5G networks in Miami.
